Marymount Hospital, Rescue, and ambulance personnel are trained in the handling of chlorine exposed patients, from past exercises dealing with chlorine, as well as ongoing training.

The area DES Coordinator will authorized re-entry into the evacuated area.


The facility emergency response will be to try and stop the leak if possible, used in the operating system or to try and contain the leak to the facility.

Chlorine gas can be slowed down by closing off the room were the Chlorine is in use, and we will try to divert as much of the chemical into the system if possible. This will slow down the amount of leakage into the atmosphere. Authorized personnel will attempt to shut off or repair chemical using safety equipment and repair kit.

To find a Chlorine leak, tie a rag on a stick, and dip rag into some 20 degree Baume' Ammonia and hold it near the suspected leak. White fumes will indicate the exact location of the leak.

NEVER PUT WATER ON A CHLORINE LEAK. The mixture of water and Chlorine will increase the rate of corrosion of the container and make the leak larger. If Chlorine gas from a leaking container can be used in the operating system, the pressure in the container can be lowered and the leak will be less serious. If the operating system cannot use it fast enough, the Chlorine should be passed into a alkaline solution, which will absorb it. Such solutions can be made using Caustic Soda or Soda Ash mixed with water. The Chlorine should be passed into the Alkaline Solution near the bottom of the container, through iron pipe or weighted rubber hose. Either Caustic Soda or Soda Ash, along with a suitable container to hold the solution, must be kept near the Chlorine unloading areas, ready for instant use.

A. The SARA Title III the will be used as the community emergency response plan.

The London Utility Commission Main Office will be the emergency response point if conditions permit. If this location cannot be used the alternative location will be the London Wastewater Treatment Plant. 

The  average rate of air change per hour (acph) in average American homes and office-type buildings under average conditions is 0.8 to 1.0 acph with doors and windows closed and ventilations systems closed down. Leaky buildings or average buildings exposed to severe weather conditions, with air change rates of 1.5 to 2.5 acph, may experience 45 to 65 percent of outdoor concentration in 30 mintues. If a structure is exposed to a hazardous concentration for an extended period of time, the chemical concentration inside the structure may approach the outside concentration. Therefore, in-place sheltering is generally applicable for release of short duration (30 minute or less) and may have limited application for releases over a period of time in excess of one hour.

The local radio and television stations will be used to notify residences to stay inside and turn off all air conditioners, heat pumps, and all outside ventilation. The local law enforcement agencies, local fire departments and rescue departments will be ask to assist in notification of residences inside the effected area.

The evacuations routes that may be used from the immediate area are East on Waterworks Road to Parker Road, then North or South on Parker Road.

In the event of a large or long term release of chlorine people in the effected area will be notified to evacuate their homes until the problem is corrected.

Evacuation orders will be given by the emergency response coordinator and all evacuations will be a joint effort by the emergency agencies.

The London Utility Commission has the Chlorine in a enclosed room that is designed for storage and use of Chlorine.

The worst case scenario would be for both of the one ton cylinders to leak at the same time.

We received our one ton tanks of Chlorine from the P.B. & S. Chemical Company Inc.

In the last five years the London Utiltiy Commission has not had a Chlorine Leak.

Chlorine is a poisonous gas, which may be fatal if inhaled. Contact on skin or eyes may cause burns. It is a Irritant and a very Corrosive material. 

Authorized peronnel only with the proper self-contained breathing apparatus and chemical protective clothing will be allow near the conataiminated area. If they are any victims they will move them to fresh air and call for medical care immediately after being move to a safe area.  The EPA and DES will be notified of any leak big or small. If the victim has contact with chlorine in their eyes they will be flushed with large amounts of water for at least 15 minutes, occasionally lifting the upper and lower eyelid. If the contact is with the skin, immediate flushing with water for 15 minutes to the effected area. If clothing is contaminated remove immediately. If chlorine was ingested immediately drink large quantities of water. DO NOT INDUCE VOMITING. DO NOT GIVE ANYTHING BY MOUTH TO A PERSON IF UNCONSCIOUS OR IF HAVING CONVULSIONS. If victim is experiences Nausea, Headache or Dizziness, victim should be moved to fresh air until these sysmptoms disapear. If breathing is dufficult, administer oxygen, keep the victim warm and resting. In the event that an individual inhales enough vapor to lose consciousness, person should be moved to fresh air at once. If breathing has stopped, artificial respiration should be given immediatley. In all cases, ensure adequate ventiation and provide respiratory protection before the person returns to work. If someone inhales the gas, they should be rushed to the hospital immediately.
